awd_titl_txt: String Theory and Quantum Field Theory: From the Planck Scale to the Hubble Scale
awd_abstract_narration:
This award funds the research activities of Professors Jacques Distler, Willy Fischler, Can Kilic, Sonia Paban and Steven Weinberg at the University of Texas at Austin.

The research of Professors Distler, Fischler, Kilic, Paban, and Weinberg is focused on the discovery and understanding of the laws that govern the universe at the most fundamental level.   As such, this research utilizes diverse and multi-pronged approaches in achieving this mission. These include studying the extensions to the Standard Model which governs the behavior of the elementary particles, and the associated experimental signatures of such extensions.   These also include the study of early-universe cosmology and present-day astrophysics, and the exploration of the physics of black holes which may shed light on how a quantum theory of gravity may be formulated.   Finally, these also include studies in relativistic quantum field theory (which is the mathematical language in which theories of the elementary particles are expressed) as well as string theory (which aims to unify all of the different particles and forces in nature).  Since the early days of modern physics, the United States has led the effort in the discovery of these fundamental laws.   Further research in this direction is therefore in the national interest, and Professors Distler, Fischler, Kilic, Paban, and Weinberg are committed to making further research contributions in these directions.  In addition, this research will involve graduate students and postdoctoral researchers and thereby provide scientific training that should serve these junior scientists well throughout their careers both within and outside of academia. Finally, these professors make science outreach a priority, and regularly deliver public lectures, in person as well as over the internet.  They also write books and articles for general audiences in order to increase science literacy and appreciation.

Many different areas of research are to be investigated as part of this research project.  Professor Distler will continue his exploration of 4D N=2 superconformal field theories and their properties, including the relation to 2D Vertex Operator Algebras. He will extend some of the lessons learned to N=1 SCFTs and he will visit afresh certain aspects of the theory of orientifolds.  Professor Fischler will continue to work with his students on quantum information in quantum gravity (using gauge-gravity duality) and the use of the quantum Hall effect in the context of quantum computation. Professor Fischler and his students are also involved in discovering possibly new observable effects in jet emissions by black holes using the gauge-gravity connection.  Professor Kilic will continue to work on dark-matter models that have uncommon experimental signatures or that can address open questions related to astrophysical observations;  he will also study techniques in collider searches designed to improve sensitivity in the case of low signal statistics and exotic final states, and he will explore how the solution to the naturalness puzzle can be experimentally probed. Professor Paban will continue to work on early-universe physics. She will explore the robustness of inflation in multifield models and the experimental signatures of models of multifield inflation compatible with string theory. Finally, Professor Weinberg will continue his work in astrophysics, and will investigate ideas that may lead to further research in elementary-particle theory.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
DISTLER: Quantum field theory is the bedrock of our understanding of physics at its most fundamental level. As we have understood quantum field theory better, the mystery of its true nature has only deepened. Perhaps surprisingly, insights from string theory have proven enormously useful in understanding ever-more-challenging questions in quantum field theory. Applying these insights has been Distler’s main focus during the period of this grant, and they have yielded useful results for (mostly supersymmetric) quantum field theories, both in 4 dimensions (where we live) and in other dimensions (in particular, in 6 dimensions), where even the existence of interacting quantum field theories is somewhat miraculous.


FISCHLER: One of the fundamental challenges in theoretical physics is the combination of quantum mechanics and gravity, commonly called “quantum gravity”. Fischler with many of his present and past students and long time collaborator Tom Banks, focused on incremental steps to sharpen our understanding of the intricate structure of quantum gravity. This included the use of tools borrowed from quantum computation, chaos theory and information theory. The outcome of this work will have an impact on various areas of theoretical physics including cosmology and will be subjected to experimental scrutiny. 


KILIC: During the grant period, Kilic explored extensions of the Standard Model of particle physics in order to address outstanding problems, with a focus on their observable signatures. Among other topics, Kilic and collaborators studied how the naturalness problem, the matter-antimatter asymmetry problem and the dark matter puzzle may be addressed by a variation of the Twin Higgs scenario. Kilic and collaborators also studied how a model of dark matter and dark interactions can address open questions in observational cosmology such as the discrepancy in the measurement of the Hubble parameter. Kilic and collaborators studied how to improve the reach of collider searches to types of particles that are difficult to observe, by utilizing machine learning methods, among others. 

Kilic makes public science engagement a priority. He is the faculty supervisor for the Physics Circus at UT Austin which conducts demonstrations to audiences of elementary school students (over 5000 students served per year). Kilic also organizes other major public science engagement activities in the physics department at the University of Texas at Austin, and he participates in public science engagement events outside of campus. 

  

PABAN: Developments in string theory suggest that, with the addition of gravity, not all effective field theories admit a consistent ultraviolet completion. The swampland conjectures are a set of criteria that effective field theories must satisfy to have this consistent completion. One of these conjectures rules out models of slow roll single-field inflation that fit Planck data well but leaves the possibility of rapid-turning multi-field inflation. During this grant, Paban and collaborators have identified criteria for multi-field theories to have long periods of inflation compatible with Planck data and have made predictions for the future detection of the Stochastic Background of Gravitational Waves.  

  

Paban has also started the Directed Reading Program in Physics, which now serves approximately twenty-five pairs of graduate-undergraduate students per semester. 

  

WEINBERG: Steven Weinberg investigated a long-standing problem in elementary particle physics, namely how the pattern of quark and lepton masses might emerge from a model of physics beyond the Standard Model. He also pursued more formal avenues by attempting to categorize types of massless particles in spacetimes of any dimensionality. 

Two books by Steven Weinberg, “Lectures on Astrophysics” and “Foundations of Modern Physics” were published by Cambridge University Press.
